isis.stitle: GAUGES AND WARNING LIGHTS - OPERATION - SPEEDOMETER

svcprocinfo.para: The vehicle speed signal is generated by the vehicle speed sensor (250) located at the rear of the transmission. This sensor contains a permanent magnet that creates a magnetic field. The sensor is mounted so that the magnetic field is repeatedly broken by a 16-tooth speedometer gear on the transmission. As the field is broken, an AC (alternating current) pulse is generated. With electronic engines, this pulse is sent on circuits 97AK and 97AJ to the ECM (see Vehicle Speed Signal from ECM). With mechanical engines, the pulse is sent over circuits 47A and 47B to the Speedo/Tach module through connector (421).

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Speed Signal From ECM
svcsubproc.para: With an electronic engine, the signal from the vehicle speed sensor is used for cruise control, engine brakes, and other functions. The ECM processes the signal from the vehicle speed sensor and sends a signal in the form of a serial data transmission, over the ATA data link circuit (a positive and negative pair of twisted wires) to the Speedo/Tach module through connector (421). The signal is also present at the ATA data link connector (137) and vehicle speed can be read using an electronic service tool (EST). For additional information on the data link, refer to GROUP 08, Electronic Engine Controls, in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

svcsubproc.title: Speedometer Gauge
svcsubproc.para: The Speedo/Tach control module processes the input signal and drives the 4-pin electronic speedometer gauge that plugs into the module. The speedometer and tachometer gauges are essentially the same except for the gauge markings.
